results.title: Nasty love = L'Amore molesto
results.creator_credit: Mario Martone, Kermit Smith, Andrea Occhipinti, Angelo Curti, Lucky Red and Teatri Uniti
results.brief_description: A woman goes to investigate her mother’s apparent suicide and ends up having to face the grim reality of her past. Amalia, the sixty-something mother of Delia, is found dead on the beach, when she should have been on her way to visit Delia in Bologna. Delia, wanting to know why her mother killed herself, journeys back to Naples to discover the truth. She encounters her mother’s supposed lover and his son, as well as her estranged father. As she continues to explore, she must face the fact that her relationship with her mother was based on jealousy and disgust as much as it was on love. She must also face up to a terrible lie she told as a child, one that questioned her mother’s fidelity and ruined the lives of everyone around her. In Italian with English subtitles. Cast includes Anna Bonaiuto, Angela Luce, Gianni Cajafa and Giovanni Viglietti.

results.title: The Legend of the holy drinker
results.creator_credit: Ermanno Olmi, Vittorio Cecchi Gori, Mario Cecchi Gori, Vincenzo de Leo, Roberta Cicutto, Aura Film, Tiger Cinematografica and Cecchi Gori Group
results.brief_description: In this award winning Italian film based on the novel by Joseph Roth, Rutger Hauer plays Andreas, an ex-miner jailed for an accidental murder. Released from prison, he is living the life of an alcoholic derelict, under the bridges of Paris until he comes into contact with a stranger, who gives him 200 francs. Andreas is confident of finding work and insists that the money should be a loan only. The stranger asks that he repay the debt to the local parish priest, as soon as he is in a position to do so. Despite Andreas’ good intentions, he is continually caught up with events or old acquaintances that part him from his money, yet strangely, the 200 francs keeps reappearing back in his wallet. Cast also includes Anthony Quayle, Sandrine Dumas, Sophie Segalen and Dominique Pinon.

results.title: For a few dollars more = Per Qualche dollari in piu [Widescreen] (S)
results.creator_credit: Sergio Leone, Alberto Grimaldi, Constantin Film, Arturo Gonzales and Produzioni Europee Associati
results.brief_description: This follow-up to Sergio Leone’s “A Fistful of Dollars” brings back Clint Eastwood as the serape-clad, cigar-chewing Man With No Name. Engaged in an ongoing battle with bounty hunter Col. Douglas Mortimer, Eastwood joins forces with his enemy to capture the homicidal bandit El Indio. Musical score by Ennio Morricone. Cast includes Clint Eastwood, Lee Van Cleef, Gian Marian Volonte and Klaus Kinski.

results.title: A Fistful of dollars = Per un pugno di dollari [Widescreen] (S)
results.creator_credit: Sergio Leone, George Papi, Harry Colombo and Jolly Film
results.brief_description: Clint Eastwood plays a cynical gunfighter who comes to a small border town and offers his services to two rivalling gangs. Neither gang is aware of his double play, and each thinks it is using him, but the stranger will outwit them both. This picture was the first instalment in a cycle commonly known as the “Dollars” trilogy, with “For a Few Dollars More” and “The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly” as follow-ups. Although the plot was admittedly borrowed from Kurosawa’s “Yojimbo”, the film contains all of Leone’s trademarks; taciturn characters, precise framing, extreme close-ups, and the haunting music of Ennio Morricone. Cast includes Marianne Koch, John Wells, W. Lukschy and Josef Egger.

results.title: Umberto D
results.creator_credit: Vittorio De Sica, Nino Misiano and DEAR Film
results.brief_description: Italian directors of the post-WWII generation, responding to the calamity of facism, to the widespread poverty in both the cities and countryside, and by necessity needing to film inexpensively and to be unencumbered by studio costs, developed a radical realist cinematic aesthetics: neo-realism. Vittorio De Sica became justly famous for his groundbreaking “The Bicycle Thieves”, utilising street locations and performances by non-actors, but it is his unsentimental “Umberto D” that now stands up as the most important film of the Italian neo-realist period. Umberto is a retired civil servant who finds himself unwanted and ignored now that his working days are over. Only his dog gives him affection; humans treat him as already dead, an old man to be shoved aside if they even see him at all. Almost documentary-like in its observation of Umberto (played with sustained brilliance by Carlo Battisti), the film quickly envelops us in the old man’s daily struggles and we find ourselves completely mesmerised by his story, we find ourselves identifying with this tale of a most ordinary “unremarkable” man. As Umberto faces his aching loneliness, and death seemingly becomes his only salvation, we as viewers have to confront our own immersion in the sterility and brutality of our industrialised urban world. The great critic Pauline Kael argued that “Umberto D” is one of those rare films that changes the viewer, that on once seeing the film you can never view the world in the same way again. Critic George Kaufman called it one of “the greatest halfdozen films ever made”. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Tales of ordinary madness = Storie di ordinaria follia
results.creator_credit: Marco Ferreri, Jacqueline Ferreri, Ginis Film and 23 Giugno
results.brief_description: Based on beat poet and counter culture celebrity Charles Bukowski’s booze soaked autobiographical writings “Erections, ejaculations, exhibitions and general tales of ordinary madness”. Directed with raw candor by Marco Ferreri (‘La Grande bouffe’, ‘The Last woman’), ‘Tales of ordinary madness’ stars Ben Gazarra as Bukowski’s alter ego - Charles Serking, a down and out poet living in Los Angeles, his writing fueled by booze, casual sex and the freedom his life style offers. When he meets Cass (Ornella Muti), a masochistic prostitute into self mutilation, Serking instantly falls for her, embarking on a passionate and self destructive affair. Cast also includes Susan Tyrell, Tania Lopert, Roy Brocksmith, Katia Berger.

results.title: The Umbrellas of Cherbourg = Les Parapluies de Cherbourg
results.creator_credit: Jacques Demy, Mag Bodard and Madeleine Films
results.brief_description: With a luscious musical score by Michel Legrand, “The Umbrellas of Cherbourg” is a lyrical fantasy about the nature of true love. Featuring astonishing colour cinematography and directed by Demy to resemble a fairy-tale, the story is about a young shop-girl (Catherine Deneuve) who falls in love with a working-class mechanic played by Nino Castelnuovo. Their romance ends when he is drafted into the Algerian War and she is left pregnant and alone. She marries the honourable merchant, Cassard (Marc Michel), but when she meets her first love years later, she has to choose between the safety of marriage and the passion and magic of her true love. Featuring glorious sets and art design, this musical has been honoured as one of the greatest of all movie musicals, winning the Palme d’Or in Cannes in 1964. The ravishing Deneuve has never been more beautiful and Castelnuovo is the epitome of Latin good looks - together they are one of the screen’s loveliest couples. This version of the film is based on the 1992 restoration by the French Ministry of Culture which faithfully restores the intense colour of the original.

results.title: Gravesend
results.creator_credit: Salvatore Stabile and Island Digital Media
results.brief_description: 22 year old filmmaker Salvatore Stabile’s debut feature owes a lot to Martin Scorsese’s gritty urban drama ‘Mean Streets’. Like that film, ‘Gravesend’ evokes a particular Brooklyn neighbourhood, painting a bleak picture of disenfranchised youth, aggressive masculinity and seething violence amongst the Italian American community. The film’s straight forward plot revolves around four friends whose usually uneventful Saturday night spins out of control when a member of the group accidentally shoots and kills someone. Their attempts to dispose of the body leads them into a bloody chain of events with inevitable tragic consequences. Cast includes Tony Tucci, Michael Parducci, Thomas Brandise and Tom Malloy.

results.title: Labyrinth
results.creator_credit: Jim Henson, Eric Rattray and Lucasfilm, Ltd.
results.brief_description: Take a journey into the Labyrinth, where nothing is as it seems. Sarah (Jennifer Connelly) spends most of her time play-acting scenes from her favourite book, The Labyrinth, or baby-sitting her younger brother, Toby. One night, frustrated with Toby’s incessant crying, she begs the goblins to take him away. When Toby actually disappears, Sarah follows him into the world of the wicked Goblin King (David Bowie), where she is given thirteen hours to conquer the Labyrinth, before her baby brother is turned into a goblin forever. An engaging fantasy film, populated by creatures created by Jim Henson’s Creature Shop, and drawing inspiration from a number of sources, including the works of Brian Froud, Maurice Sendak and M. C. Escher. Includes a special behind-the-scenes featurette detailing the making of Labyrinth.

results.title: A Short film about killing [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Krzysztof Kieslowski and Zespoly Filmowe,Film Polski
results.brief_description: This previously unreleased feature length of Kieslowski’s A Short Film About Killing is a film about killing, murder, a drifter and corporal punishment. The film seems as much about the polarities between the psychology of the murderer (representing perhaps the inner self or subconscious) and society (our conscious sense of the world) and our disconnection to it. Scenes from a drifter’s life are interspersed between those of a taxi driver who without reason is brutally murdered by the drifter. An unlawful crime is now in the hands of the law as the boy responsible faces the court and imminent sentencing, a legal death. Kieslowski does not try to explain the killer’s motivation but uses an unusual choreographed camera style to portray a disturbing disconnection between the drifter and the brutal murder of his victim. The light in the film is pulled from the edges of the frame to highlight the subject but also separate him visually from the outside world and his actions. As the court case proceeds we learn less about the motives of the killer and more of the cold morals of corporal punishment. The chilling parallels of the legal system and the unspoken psychology of the disconnected drifter are sealed with the verdict.ESC.
